title: Extends right to vote to aliens lawfully admitted for permanent residence in the U.S.
summary: Extends the right to vote in all elections to aliens lawfully admitted for permanent residence in the United States.

       Introduced by Sens. DILAN, DIAZ, PARKER -- read twice and ordered print-

       AN ACT to amend the election law, the town law and the education law, in
         relation to the right to vote

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. The legislature hereby finds and declares that the right to
    2  vote is an essential part of membership in the communities which make up
    3  the state of New York. In order to ensure that all  persons  who  perma-
    4  nently  and  legally reside in our state have a voice and a stake in the
    5  decisions made by the political process, it is necessary and  proper  to
    6  extend  the  right  to  them,  as citizens of New York state, to vote in
    7  elections for offices and on issues which affect them.
    8    S 2. Subdivision 1 of section 5-102 of the election law is amended  to
    9  read as follows:
   10    1.  No  person  shall  be  qualified  to  register for and vote at any
   11  election unless he OR SHE is a citizen of the United States OR AN  ALIEN
   12  LAWFULLY ADMITTED FOR PERMANENT RESIDENCE IN THE UNITED STATES and is or
   13  will be, on the day of such election, eighteen years of age or over, and
   14  a  resident of this state and of the county, city or village for a mini-
   15  mum of thirty days next preceding such election.
   16    S 3. Paragraph (g) of subdivision 5 of section 5-210 of  the  election
   17  law,  as  amended by chapter 179 of the laws of 2005, is amended to read
   18  as follows:

   20  OR  AN  ALIEN  LAWFULLY  ADMITTED  FOR PERMANENT RESIDENCE IN THE UNITED
   21  STATES, is or will be at least eighteen years old not later than  Decem-
   22  ber thirty-first of the calendar year in which he or she registers and a
   23  resident of the county or city to which application is made.

   40  AN ALIEN LAWFULLY ADMITTED FOR PERMANENT RESIDENCE IN THE UNITED STATES;
   41  that I am of the age of eighteen years or more;  that  I  have  been  an
   42  inhabitant  of the State for the past year, a resident of the county for
   43  the past four months and for the thirty days past an actual resident  of
   44  this  city  school  district  and am therefore qualified to vote at this
   45  election."  If the person challenged so swears or  affirms,  he  OR  SHE
   46  shall  be  permitted  to  vote  at such election; but if he OR SHE shall
   47  refuse to so swear or affirm, he OR SHE shall not be given a  ballot  or
   48  be permitted to vote.
   49    S 18. This act shall take effect on the first of January next succeed-
   50  ing the date on which it shall have become a law.
memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1339

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the election law, the town law and the education law, in
relation to the right to vote

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
This bill would further the democratic principles of American society by
extending the right to vote in Federal, State, and local elections
conducted in New York State to aliens lawfully admitted for permanent
residence in the United States.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
Various sections of the Election Law are amended to effectuate this
right: §5-102 (qualifications of voters); §5-21O (voter registration);
§7-122 (absentee ballot); §7-123 (military ballots for military
personnel and their spouses, parents, and children); §7-125 (special
presidential ballots); and  §8-504 (challenges to absentee, military,
and special presidential ballots). In each case, the sections are
amended to extend the right to vote to an "alien lawfully admitted for
permanent residence in the United States."

Similar amendments are made to Town Law §84-a (absentee ballots in
special town elections) and §213-b (absentee ballots in town improvement
district elections); as well as the following sections of the Education
Law: §2012 (common or union-free school district elections); §2018-a
(absentee ballots in same); §2018-b (absentee ballots for same by poll
registration); §2603 (elections in city school districts with under
125,000 residents); and §2609 (challenges in such city school
districts).

JUSTIFICATION:
Although it is commonly believed that voting is a right restricted to
U.S. citizens under the Federal and State Constitutions, this is not
necessarily the case. In fact, the view that voting must be restricted
to citizens is a recent one.

Not only is the belief that only citizens can vote historically wrong,
it is not even accurate in New York State today. For example,
non-citizens are currently permitted to vote in New York City community
school board elections, provided they have children attending public
school (Education Law §2590-c(3)). This is permissible under the State
Constitution, because it permits voting by "citizens" of New York State,
the definition of which needs not be coterminous with U.S. citizens. The
United States Constitution allows the individual States to set forth the
qualifications of voters in Federal elections, provided that they are
not unduly restrictive. Non-citizens are also eligible to vote in other
elections, such as those for governing bodies of Federal community-based
anti-poverty programs. These provisions are based on the logic that the
best decisions are those made through the democratic process, involving

all of those who are affected thereby. This bill would extend this logic
to general Federal, State, and local elections.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
January 1st after enactment.
